ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture + virtual lab
This course was a combination of live virtual lectures and virtual labs.
We had recorded lectures on how to perform methods used in each lab as well as a mandatory live virtual lecture to discuss and answer any questions.
Live virtual lecture with virtual labs and project work.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to use multiple platforms/tools that enable astronomers to observe celestial objects. Also learned basic principles and methodologies of how to perform data analysis on observational data.
I obtained a better understanding of astronomical observations (using telescopes, taking photos, and editing images). I also now have a better understanding of astronomy in general.

This course taught the practical aspect of much of the astronomy theory I have learned in my classes. Getting to actually work with photometry, or with a spectrograph, were great lessons that illustrated how to go from an instrument and an idea to doing actual science.

Fewer than I had hoped for. The class focuses very little on stuff like learning star and constellation names, and more on telescope operation and types of photography and analysis. Fine if the labs are well-designed and explained, but they were mediocre and at times very tedious.

I learned the essentials of telescope components and calculating plate scales, field-of-view, and the properties of lenses. Additionally, we learned methods that deduced the properties of celestial objects by observable parameters obtained from CCD photometry and astrometry (e.g. determining stellar classifications from color index, position of moons of Jupiter and their orbital periods, etc).

Operating telescopes remotely, picking targets based on rise/set times, spectroscopy, photometry, fitting to sparse data, research writing, astronomical image processing. The functioning of telescopes and CCD cameras, star life cycles and chemical composition.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great coverage and foundation on basics of observational astronomy. Lectures are engaging and hands-on. Labs allowed students to carry out their own observations. Could provide students with more materials/documentations/decks to refer to when doing lab reports.
This course is very hands-on. Going through the labs definitely helped with my learning.

The course has a very open format, due to telescope time being limited based on whether. Thus the timing of actual lab work was convenient for scheduling. The classes were engaging and the lab work itself was interesting and a unique online experience compared to the lecture nature of my other classes. It was incredibly rewarding to operate a telescope from my hope many miles away and then study that data.

Strengths: You learn various imaging techniques. It's also a pretty easy lab substitute for Astro majors. 
Weaknesses:  I found most of the additional help from the instructor to be unnecessarily convoluted. It also took them several months to grade the majority of our labs, making it difficult to gauge where we were at in the course.
Observation sessions should be run by teacher, or else TAs should be briefed much more thoroughly, because they were often very rough. Labs could involve far less busy work

The content was very interesting but it was quite a lot of work for only a half-credit class. I believe this  could be improved by having fewer labs, especially because being clouded out was an issue with several.
The course was self-directed in many aspects, with supplementary weekly discussions that really helped with the time zone differences and kept me engaged while still remaining flexible.
It is too much of a time commitment for only half a credit

The ability to carry out actual observing was very helpful and a lot of fun. The labs were also very interesting as they covered a range of topics in astronomy and included various data analysis techniques. The live lectures/demonstrations of lab material were very helpful in understanding the context of the lab and in making its instructions clear.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learning was fine in a virtual environment, which was aided by the fact we could control the telescopes virtually via our own computers.

Working with the telescopes, which is normally done via a computer anyway, replicated the real-life experience (minus the long walk up to the observatory) and thus the course worked really well in the online format!
Lab worked quite well because we could control the Yale telescope remotely.

The remote observing worked very well, allowing students to learn how to operate the telescope and also reflecting how modern astronomers carry out their observations. The optional in-person observing sessions would have been very useful for using the telescopes directly, but unfortunately weather did not cooperate.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Would definitely recommend if you are interested in getting an intro on astronomy and the more technical/hands-on with data analysis and how astronomers work in the field.
Yes! This is one of my favorite courses at Yale so far. Strongly recommended for anyone that is curious about/interested in astronomy.
I would! I think it is a great intro to learning about astronomy concepts and applying them to actual work.
I'd recommend it for Astro majors as a substitute for the second term of physics lab. The labs are too difficult and tedious for someone looking for a fun elective.
No. Pretty boring overall, professor gave literally no feedback on assignments until last few weeks of semester
Yea, however, the student should be prepared to complete long lab reports. Though, if they put in the effort, they should do well in the course no matter what.

Definitely! This course is really friendly to those with any level of astronomy knowledge. The course itself isn't extremely technical but teaches valuable skills regarding telescope operation and broad main ideas in astronomy.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in astronomy or astrophysics, as well as to any amateur astronomers.
